comments.commentBody: In the closing ceremonies there were a slew of American flags but none (that I saw) from other countries. Whereas in the Olympics, for example, medal winners' ceremonies feature flags from the runners up.  If you're going to do flags, how about one for each of the 33 countries (I'm quoting the number from memory) represented in the US Open. Just a thought.
Spain and the world should be proud. Nadal earned his mark in Tennis history.

I've got a hard time with this.  On one hand, I think unions are critical to improve the lot of workers at places like Walmart, where workers are told how to apply for medicaid instead of being given decent pay or benefits.  Then I see unions whose members get good pay, lots of paid time off, free health insurance, and pensions.  They protect these "rights" even at the expense of new union members... or the tax paying public in the case of public sector unions.  I find this frustrating beyond belief.

Excellent post by David L.
We are fighting the the last (as in previous) war. Public agencies often do.
Also, central bankers pettifog about inflation the way my enfeebled great-aunt used to sermonize about sex.

It is also important to keep in mind that many countries prefer to have socialist policies (charity through Govt) rather than individual charity e.g. Sweden, Norway or even India have more progressive policies (both tax and education) than countries like US where the culture is of individual charity. It might be better to look at the outcome of charity, income inequality rankings across countries, and that may reveal a different picture of " revealed generosity".
http://en.wikipedia.org...

Does the offensive coordinator have any confidence in Mark Sanchez? Do the Jets braintrust think they can win a Super Bowl with a quarterback whose can only attempt short "dump off" passes. If so why did they get rid of Chad Pennington?

Hey, NYT, thanks! So this is what it takes to get some attention from you: have our commissioner step down. Wish we had know as much earlier. Never mind our games, we'll make sure to reorganize more often!
Maybe instead of harassing female reporters, some of these guys need to be doing their damn job in getting ready to play.

Tennis is such an amazing test of physical, mental and spiritual tenacity as displayed today in this fantastic US OPEN!!! NADAL you should be a King! You are incredible and a bright light of inspiration. It was beautiful the way Nadal congratulated Novak on his sportsmanship and said he is a role model to kids in his acceptance speech; what a rare kindness to behold not often seen in sports. These athletes deserve their prize money more than actors and silly celebrities who do nothing. BTW: Nadal has a foundation for children that he and his mother head.

PS>>>(After dealing with the rain delays and checking in at work on my computer, it was a shock when ESPN cut away from Rafael Nadal as he held his trophy! Thank goodness I had USTA.ORG on my computer and could run over and watch the ceremony extended to its rightful time limit! Next time, everyone keep your computer on!)

Incredible how Rafa keeps improving, for someone who peaked that young and who has already won everything. Now he seems to have a killer service too. Who will stop him in the next few years?

If his knees resist, we are into something historic here. By the way, many "armchair coaches" predicted a year ago that Rafa would never be able to beat a top ten player again. You know who you are. Good call !

PS1: why criticize Roger to cheer Rafa? Federer is a true gentleman as is Nadal . There is a lot of respect between the two of them. Federer has always been gracious, winning or losing. I remember him (when he beat Rafa at their first Wimbledon final, I think) saying that he should rush and win tournaments before Rafa started winning them all. He was right!

PS2: Rafa and the use of steroids: Bullocks!

Congratulations, Rafa! A much-deserved and inspiring victory!

Career Golden Slam and 9th major at age 24! What a legend!!! Vamos!!!

Proud to be a Spaniard! The awesome thing about Nadal is not only how great tennis player he is, but how humble and great person is. This is a helluva win for Nadal, but a great achieve for tennis sport.

Congrats Nadal for your unbelievable career and for representing our Nation, Spain, to the World, as good as you do it.

Viva NYC! Viva España!

Lefties should have to compete in their own division. I'm now questioning the greatness of laver, conners, mcenroe. And in this "inside out" era the advantage is even greater.
Is this Fed Fan sour grapes? You bet it is but its also true. Ask Uncle Tony.
Go Rafa!  I couldn't be happier to see this classy, sweet guy finally win the elusive one.

Rafael Nadal , 24, my hero and world number one has won a spectacular United States Open  in four sets against world number three Novak Djokovic. The Spaniard completed a career Golden Slam which takes him to nine Grand Slam titles. In winning the United States Open, Nadal has joined the ranks of Roger Federer, Andre Agassi, Roy Emerson, Rod Laver, Don Budge and Fred Perry the all-time greats of tennis. Nadal becomes only the seventh man in history to complete the set of majors - Wimbledon, the French, Australian and US Opens. Rafael Nadal is the first man since Rod Laver in 1969 to win the French Open, Wimbledon and US Open in the same year. "I think for the first time in my career I played a very, very good match in this tournament," Nadal said. "That's my feeling. I played my best match in the U.S. Open out there at the most important moment." Undoubtedly Rafael Nadal is the best tennis player in the world today.
Very nice except for the cross of ZAMBONI and INTS... I suppose the latter has something to do with interference? No idea what the former is. Just guessing at the last letter isn't much fun...
How about an Ollie Perez pinata night?
Dunking booth with Ollie Perez?  3 balls for a buck...
Perez should offer his face up to a pie throwing contest.

Sorry, gents. The Rays are #1. Again. Small ball, defense and pitching. When the occasional long ball comes, it's a winner.

I admired the Yankees for a while, hanging in there, creeping ahead of the Rays, but right now they do not look like champions.

Anyone who shows up gets a free medical examination by one of the Mets' trainers.   Maybe they'll find a torn meniscus inside your stomach or diagnose a brain tumor as a concussion.   Otherwise, how about letting every fan in attendance audition for a place in the 2011 bullpen?  Maybe Manuel can find an "eighth-inning guy" to pass along to his successor.

The question marks about Javy Vazquez able to pitch in the AL East, Burnett making the proper adjustments & tenacity issues, Hughes number of games at the start of this season have come back to haunt the team during the September stretch drive for a run at the division title. Pettitte's stamina has pretty much shed serious doubt on the Yanks getting past the Rays for the postseason.
A fine series, thank you. When do we get the "Guide to N.F.L. Offenses"?
INTS are interceptions, while I suspect you've never been to a hockey game (or an ice rink) if you're not familiar with a ZAMBONI. Zambonis are cool (then again, so are ice rinks)!

@ArtLvr, ZAMBONI is the name of Sarah Palin's next child, should she choose to procreate yet again; it's also the machine used to smooth the ice on a hockey rink.  INTS are interceptions (in football statistics).
